His right wing, under the command of Lentulus1, rested on a small stream² whose preci- pitous banks and the swampy ground which it had recently delu ged formed a sufficient protection against a flank attack³. Here were the Cilician legion and the cohorts which Afranius had brought from Spain4. Except for a small detachment of 600⁶, there were no cavalry on this wing. ln the centre were the steady Syrian legions with Scipio as commander. The left wing', where Pompcy himself commanded in chief, consisted of the two legions which‘had been withdrawn from Caesar before the outbreak of the war, under theimmediate charge of the fierce Domitius, while the rest of the legionaries filled the space between the centre and the wingsl.
